author: Josh Galt
title: Farm to Fork Supply Chain - Insects
description: The insects as food & feed sector can be a sustainable alt-protein solution, but fragmentation keeps consumers and farmers from connecting

assessments.note:
I personally like the idea of creating a real-time traceable supply chain DApp for all insect related products. It is great! The idea is massive and its implications.

However, while the idea is great, the proposal has some weaknesses. 

In effect the idea is great, but a Catalyst proposal is a step up from an idea. The proposal is being assessed here. 

The proposer does identify a very big global market (and an initial one in Southeast Asia) that the DApp would focus on. I am wondering whether centralized Apps or traceability services exist for this market that this proposed DApp can be compared to? If yes, it would have been good to be able to compare their specific weaknesses and how the proposed DApp would address those issues and provide users with additional value. 

If these centralized Apps or services do not exist yet, is there a reason why they are not available? 

Building a DApp (or application) is just one part of providing any true product traceability - it seems to require integration with a comprehensive traceability system with procedures and guidelines. 

It is unclear to me whether this is a DApp that is part of a wider proposed system. Or is it a DApp that will also be able to integrate with existing traceability platforms. If a new traceability system is being proposed - I fail to see the details of that system in the proposal. 

A real-time traceable supply chain DApp would be one component- however the proposal would have benefited from fleshing out other aspects - such as strengths, limitations, and risks of the new traceability system or others that it will integrate with. The ultimate success of a decentralized insect related traceability system may not depend only on the DApp itself. 

I would have liked to see other components of the bigger jigsaw addressed as well - in order to assess its full impact and whether it will be able to add value to the Cardano ecosystem. 

The issue is that if the proposed traceability system is not up to par as a whole, the DApp might not add value to the Cardano ecosystem. How will compliance be ensured? How will consumers be able to rely on the soundness of information that is accessible via the DApp? How will identity be managed? WIll Atala Prism ( decentralized identity solution built on the Cardano blockchain) be used? Etc...

The proposer specifies that a full pitch deck and plan outline are available on request. The proposal would have benefited from their inclusion - as without them it is difficult to assess the impact of a DApp alone on such a sector. The DApp is a tool - but the full solution of the proposed traceability system (or integration with other systems) - is key to measure the potential benefits to the Cardano ecosystem. 

The platform may be able to connect consumers, brands, and farmers in real time, removing the need for trust in institutions by transparent verification of the entire process - but the issue of trust among the participants remains. Maybe institutions do not need to be trusted, but how is the new DApp verifying that the information on the blockchain is correct? How are key elements verified (quality, volumes, sourcing, deliveries, etc..)?
Great idea, however there is no implementation plan

Seems like a valid use case for this challenge and therefore addresses the challenge. I note that the proposal still seems to be in the development stage and that a team will be required to build the Dapp. Would be great to get an update on how teambuilding is progressing.

As it is quoted
 in the proposal: "connect consumers, brands, and farmers in real time, removing the need for trust in institutions by transparent verification of the entire process". The author seeks to encourage and practice trade around insects, which can have different uses, such as food, by building a platform that makes the connections mentioned above. With this, the App would have a great impact both for the ecological sector (it is a more sustainable economy than the production of traditional proteins) and for the economy. However, the author does not emphasize where ADA would be used in this project. Naturally, I think it would be through financial transactions, but it would be interesting to clarify this issue better, after all, the financing would be made by the Catalyst community.

The concept of insect farming and distribution as a source for nutrition for humans and animals, coupled with a dApp that would guarantee the supply chain is a very interesting concept, highly sustainable, with the potential to bring along a new community to the Cardano ecosystem. However, on the dApp description side, there is not much information given.

Although the proposer lists relevant experience briefly, it is not directly supported by links to a relevant LinkedIn profile and other organizations. However, a cursory search via Google confirms some of the experience listed, although the proposer could have made it easier for voters to access this information via his proposal.  What is missing, however, is the experience of the team members, the DApp developers, even the traceability system experts as this is a traceability DApp. The budget is not outlined clearly and broken down into identifiable items, which is a problem for a project of this ambition. The proposer includes a general timetable for the DApp development and a pilot project stage, which is good. However, there are no technical details about the proposed DApp, its potential use of smart contracts and challenges and risks to implementation are not addressed.

Currently no plan. this is a request for developers to join the proposer and come up with one. Thus as it currently stands it is unlikely to succeed. Please find collaborators and produce a detailed plan.

At this stage it is difficult to rate the proposal higher as it is lack key ingredients for successful implementation; namely developers to produce the Dapp. I also note the author is engaged in finding a team which will greatly improve this application and the plan that needs to be filed with that. Any further updates would be appreciated by the community I feel and improve likelihood of project going forward.

The author says he has experience with the issue of insects, as well as in startup-type industries and being a skilled communicator. However, it does not mention if it has already had previous contact with the Catalyst universe, with blockchain and etc., which would be essential to develop the project within our community. He shows up with the intention of hiring a team, developers, but it would be beneficial if he made it clear who are the people he intends to call to compose the team. I also missed a profile on linkedin, or even a more detailed description of his activities in the insect business, which arouses our curiosity and could bring more credibility to the author. If such information were added, as well as further clarification about the future team, it would be better.

Even though the proposer has not provided any links to his past experience, from the details regarding many aspects of insect farming and distribution one can tell that he's been in this business for some time. But while the project describes in detail everything insect related, it lacks entirely on the app side. I understand the proposer is not a developer and is looking to collaborate with one, but since this is a challenge for dApps it would be hard to overlook this aspect.

This proposal in my view is heavier on the idea and general concept side, but weaker on the specific implementation side. It does provide a very general roadmap with milestones and a time horizon for achievement. However, there is not enough information about the proposed DApp and its specific functionalities that would result in a successful (!) traceability system. The design and characteristics of the DApp are key to its success and to being able to assess how effectively it addresses the challenge, as well as its linkage to a good traceability system. 

Success in this challenge is not just building a novel application of top of Cardano, but the application also has to be viable in order to attract users. 

The proposal lacks sufficient Metrics/KPIs that would help define the success of the proposal. To me the proposal would need to drill down on metrics and KPIs more, as building a DApp is not sufficient for the proposed system - it is part of a larger farm-to-fork traceability endeavor that is being proposed. More Metrics/KPIs are needed to assess success and feasibility.
No detailed plan to discern if it is feasible.

Good information provided but there remains the issue of team building that will be essential to the project getting built. The idea itself seems widely received by the community and this tells me once team building underway the community is likely to have a positive response. The use cases for such a Dapp could well turn this project into something significant.

Here we see something that, unfortunately, happens quite a lot during the launch of proposals. We have a very extensive and interesting explanation of why this idea is relevant, but few lines intended to explain how things would happen in practice. We know that the intention of this idea is to create an App that enhances the trade of insects, makes the contact between producers, consumers, distributors and etc. more direct and simple. But how, exactly? I think it would be good to explain in more detail how the App was going to be built, by which parts. We are informed of the first steps, up to 5 months of action, of what would happen. However, in a very superficial way ... I felt it speaks of a more detailed, more complete action plan, that would guide the action beyond the first 5 months. In addition, the money requested is not quoted, it is not explained how it would be used, in which parts it would be applied and so on. Unfortunately, much detail is lacking in relation to the practical application of the project.

As mentioned above, this project covers only one half of it, the half about app development is not detailed as the proposer lack the knowledge to provide it. Therefor I cannot assess the proposal correctly and I would highly suggest that it be re-submitted for the next fund. And maybe in the meantime he can get in touch with a developer who could at least help him in formulating a clearer plan.

solution: A real-time traceable supply chain DApp for all insect related products, connecting organic waste inputs through farming to feed to fork
experience: 5+ years in the insect vertical, execom member with INTL organizations, fundraising for industry startups, global speaker, profiled in media
